IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: To help each person develop his or her full potential through language and literacy.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The mission of the Atlanta Speech School is to help each person develop his or her full potential through language and literacy.
IRS990.Description: The Atlanta Speech School was founded in 1938 to serve children and adults, primarily in metropolitan Atlanta. The organization is particularly focused on helping young children develop language and become proficient readers, despite any obstacles to learning they may have. Our students and clients include those who are deaf or hard of hearing, have learning disabilities including dyslexia, and have speech and language disabilities, as well as children who are typically developing. In our four schools, we serve approximately 380 preschoolers and elementary-age children annually. The four schools are: the KATHERINE HAMM CENTER (for infants, toddlers and elementary-age children who are deaf or hard of hearing by helping them learn through listening, spoken language and reading); the WARDLAW SCHOOL (elementary school for children with learning disabilities including dyslexia); STEPPING STONES (preschool for young children with significant speech and/or language delays); and, the ANNE & JIM KENAN PRESCHOOL (for typically developing children.)

Activity2.Description: The Atlanta Speech School operates numerous clinical programs for children and adults that help support language development and literacy. These include: - The SPEECH PATHOLOGY & AUDIOLOGY CLINIC offers a variety of services including evaluation, intervention, and audiology. - The LEARNING EVALUATION CLINIC provides comprehensive psycho-educational evaluations and follow-up planning for children ages four to eighteen. - The OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY CLINIC serves children from infancy toadolescence who experience difficulties in sensory integration and motor skills development. - The LEARNING LAB provides individual and small-group remediation for students who struggle in school.

Activity3.Description: The Atlanta Speech School's Rollins Center for Language & Learning is a professional development program that trains and coaches teachers of children from pre-school through 8th grade, focusing on the teacher providing the students with evidenced based language and literary instruction. We place a priority on achieving improved outcomes for students from low socio-economic circumstances. In order for our youngest, most vulnerable citizens to have the opportunity to be successful in school and break the poverty cycle that is fueled by illiteracy for generation to generation. The crisis that exists for these children is evidenced by the fact that 82% of our children in Georgia from low income families were below grade level.Since 2006, the Rollins Center has trained 509 educators who have impacted the lives of more than 4,500 children. The primary work of the Rollins Center for Language & Learning is through school partnerships, particularly with public schools and school systems and agencies providing preschool services to children disadvantaged by poverty.

ActivityOther.Description: In addition to its four schools and numerous clinical programs, the Atlanta Speech School offers after-school programs and summer camps that provide children remediation and enrichment opportunities. The Learning Lab provides specialized individual or small group remediation for children who struggle in school.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Atlanta Speech School believes a strong, well-managed endowment can provide a financial cornerstone for the organization's service to future generations. The Atlanta Speech School conservatively manages its invested funds, following a spending formula that allows for the core of the endowment to remain protected over time and the earnings to be used to support the organization's annual operations and financial aid program.

IRS990ScheduleE.PubViaBroadcastMediaExpln: WEBSITE, BROCHURES, PAMPHLETS AND APPLICATIONS STATE THAT THE ATLANTA SPEECH SCHOOL DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE ON THE BASIS OF GENDER, AGE, RACE, RELIGION, OR NATIONAL ORIGIN IN PROVIDING SERVICES TO THE PUBLIC OR IN EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES. AND LOAN PROGRAMS AND ATHLETIC AND OTHER SCHOOL ADMINISTERED PROGRAMS.
IRS990ScheduleE.GovtFinancialAidExplanation: THE SCHOOL RECEIVES FUNDS FROM SEVERAL GEORGIA COUNTIES UNDER BABIES CAN'T WAIT, A STATEWIDE INTERAGENCY SERVICE DELIVERY SYSTEM FOR INFANTS AND TODDLERS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DELAYS OR DISABILITIES AND THEIR FAMILIES. AMOUNT RECEIVED WAS $25,583.

Form990ScheduleIPartIII.MethodOfValuation: Market value of portion of tuition recipients are not required to pay

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Families are required to apply for financial aid by submitting the parent's financial statement form through the School and Student Service for Financial Aid (SSS) of the National Association of Independent Schools. A copy of the parent's financial form, income tax statements, W-2's and specific reasons for seeking assistance are submitted to the School's Chief Financial Officer. SSS provides the School and parent its analysis of the parent's financial statement along with their recommendation on the amount the parents are able to pay toward tuition. The School's Financial Aid Committee reviews the information provided by the parents and SSS. Each application is fully discussed and agreement is reached on the amount of financial aid to be awarded.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: After a draft version of the Form 990 has been prepared, the draft is sent to the audit committee. This committee supervises the financial compliance affairs of the School. At the audit committee meeting, members discuss any issues or concerns they may have with the draft Form 990. After discussion, a motion will be made to accept the draft version of the Form 990. The approved version of the Form 990 is sent to the Board of Directors. Any board member comments and changes are reflected in the version of the Form 990 that is filed. The approved Form 990 is then signed by an officer and filed with the IRS.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Upon election of a person to the Board of Directors, the School conflict of interest policy must be signed. The School sends an annual questionnaire to the Board of Directors so that any new conflicts of interest or changes in conflicts of interest can be documented and the School can act appropriately when a conflict is identified.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Compensation for the Executive Director is approved by the Board of Director's Personnel Committee. The Executive Director's performance is reviewed annually, and the Committee considers comparable salary data for executive directors of organizations in like size and activities. The Board of Directors approves annual salary increases for staff, including senior management.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The School makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy and financial statements available to the public upon request.
